Ted Striker.Action: Shoos a bird away gently by knocking on the glass instead of aggressive behavior.
Drinks beer while flying and acts cockily.
Lies in a hot, dusty hotel room, drinking and smoking, showing signs of distress and self-neglect.
Reflects on his past fear and cowardice but acknowledges how fate made a hero out of him.
Wipes sweat and struggles with a fan, showing vulnerability and humanizing himself.
Successfully lands a plane with no crew, saving 120 people.
Avoids flying after the war due to trauma, showing lack of confidence initially.
Receives widespread recognition and job offers for his heroic actions.
Struggles comically with a table fan causing a tornado force wind, indicating clumsiness or lack of control in mundane tasks.
Shows concern and urgency about the launch of the XR-2300, tries to explain its importance to the boy.
Races out to catch a taxi and gives clear directions, showing determination to act quickly.
Determines he must stop the Mercury shuttle flight, pushes through crowd to act on it.
Rushing up to agent and asking for mission control, shows urgency but agent is unhelpful and he remains polite.
Decides he must stop the Mercury shuttle flight and pushes through a crowd determinedly.
Asks for mission control location but receives no clear directions and appears puzzled.
Passes travellers in rags without comment, moves toward information counter.
Attempts to get clear information from the info agent, shows patience despite unhelpful responses.
Looks directly into the camera with a confused expression after the agent is shot.
Moves through the terminal looking for information, approaches the information counter proactively.
Fails to get clear directions from the information agent, appears confused by vague or unhelpful responses.
Questions the information agent about 'mission control' despite unclear or unhelpful answers.
Expresses concern about the safety of the Mercury flight and tries to warn others despite being dismissed.
Insists on talking to Elaine urgently, showing care and concern.
Is called crazy and sick by others but remains sincere in his warnings.
Insists the Mercury flight is unsafe and tries to warn others despite being dismissed.
Is called crazy and mentally feeble by others, suggesting doubts about his mental state.
Identifies a wiring issue that could cause shorts under high temperatures, showing technical insight.
His concerns are dismissed by Simon as seeing bugs where they don't exist, implying possible overwork or paranoia.
Pulls away from Elaine when she tries to comfort him, responds harshly.
Rants passionately about design specifications, trying to prove his point.
Rants about design specifications and insists there is nothing wrong with him despite others' concerns.
Is overworked and possibly having a breakdown, leading to being forcibly subdued and injected with a sedative.
Accepts concern from Stella Barrington, a nurse, but politely declines help.
Acknowledges Dr. Barrington's work respectfully.
Muttering to himself and insisting he is perfectly sane despite others perceiving him as mentally ill.
Recognizes and correctly identifies Dr. Barrington as a world-renowned agronomist and is familiar with his work.
Avoids further conversation and leaves abruptly when offered help by Stella, the nurse.
Persistently tries to talk to Elaine despite her reluctance and rejection.
Expresses emotional vulnerability by asking Elaine what happened to their relationship.
Ignores Elaine's advice to return to the hospital and insists on going to mission control.
Accepts spaghetti from Elaine and engages in conversation with her.
Expresses suspicion that Simon Kurtz put him in the hospital to get him out of the way.
Refers to another patient (Sammy Davis Junior) with some empathy and knowledge of his condition.
Does not resist Elaine's decision to leave him for Simon, shows no hostility.
Shows awareness of being manipulated by Simon Kurtz and questions his situation in the mental hospital.
Is in a mental hospital, undergoing electro-shock treatment, and appears mentally unstable.
Attempts to take pills but is stopped by nurse demanding payment, showing some confusion or distraction.
Engages in conversation with Elaine, showing some clarity and memory about people around him.
Turns away when Elaine tries to kiss him goodbye, insists on no goodbyes and tells her to just go.
Turns away from Elaine's kiss and insists on no goodbyes, showing emotional control and decisiveness.
Fails to recognize the electro-shock device and suffers convulsions when Elaine activates it, indicating a lack of awareness.
Responds politely to Mrs. Gooch's request and continues moving through a crowded terminal without hesitation.
Insists on seeing Bud Kruger urgently despite lacking an appointment, claiming it's a matter of life or death.
Bolts past receptionist and grabs a door knob on the wall, ignoring her protests.
Falls unconscious into the arms of two guards and is dragged away without resistance.
Struggles to free his hands while tied up, showing determination to escape and possibly help others.
Struggles to free his hands while tied to a chair, notices a cigarette rolling toward flammable oil rags.
Flies out of an exploding storage room, gets up, brushes himself off, and heads to the ticket counter calmly.
Immediately tries to buy a ticket from a scalper after finding the official tickets sold out.
Stops at the door surrounded by boarding passengers, appears hesitant or passive when confronted by the psychiatrist.
Spots Elaine and moves towards her with urgency, trying to stop the flight to prevent danger.
Insists on getting into the cockpit despite Elaine and others telling him to take his seat.
Spots Elaine and moves towards her with urgency, attempts to stop the flight by getting into the cockpit.
Fails to get into the cockpit as Elaine locks the door before he can enter.
Refuses to admit that he is sick despite obvious problems.
Refuses to admit that he's sick despite obvious problems.
His condition worsens after being informed about Simon, indicating poor mental or emotional control.
Ignores Elaine's attempts to communicate and help while obsessively working in the garden.
Shows intense focus and determination to solve the shuttle problem despite emotional distance.
Ignores Elaine's attempts to communicate and works frantically ripping up plants and throwing them onto a mud pile.
Claims to have figured out what's wrong with the shuttle, showing some insight or realization.
Behaves obsessively and does not engage with others, indicating possible instability or lack of control.
Accepts a magazine from Mary politely despite being distracted.
Appears distracted and disengaged when offered reading material.
Distractedly accepts a magazine and fails to engage meaningfully, showing lack of focus.
Sits quietly looking out the window without taking initiative or action.
Breathes deeply on an oxygen unit, appears tense but does not interact negatively with others.
Breathes deeply on an oxygen unit, appears to be calming himself before a stressful situation.
Throws water on his face and tries to compose himself in the washroom, showing vulnerability.
Warns Elaine about the danger of the ship and insists on aborting the mission, showing concern for others' safety.
Throws water on his face and tries to compose himself in the washroom, showing some self-awareness and attempt to regain control.
Flushes a paper towel down the toilet causing a malfunction and nearly getting trapped, showing poor judgment and lack of practical skill.
Recognizes the critical safety issues with the ship and insists the mission be aborted, demonstrating situational awareness and concern for safety.
Walks down the aisle checking overhead panels, tries to identify problems on the ship.
Holds a hanky to his head wound and downplays injury to Stella.
Admits to Stella that if a relationship isn't working, you can't force it.
Opens up about his confusion and feelings regarding love and his relationship.
Reminisces fondly about laughing and good times with Elaine, showing emotional sincerity.
Engages in a thoughtful conversation about love and relationships, showing reflective and introspective thinking.
Describes being hit by a vacuum cleaner after opening a panel, indicating a moment of clumsiness or lack of situational awareness.
Locked in loving embrace and laughing with partner, expressing closeness and joy.
Tells the story to passengers despite their hostile reaction (hissing and throwing vegetables).
Shares personal history about being in an asylum and insists on his sanity, showing vulnerability and sincerity.
Attempts to drink but pours it on his forehead, indicating nervousness or self-consciousness.
Takes a stress pill offered by Stella when feeling overwhelmed.
Pops a stress pill automatically when offered, but misses his face with his drink.
Becomes slightly hypnotized and unresponsive during a relaxation exercise.
Elaine says 'Then Ted was right!' indicating trust in his judgment.
Elaine says 'Then Ted was right!' indicating Ted had correctly anticipated the danger despite others' disbelief.
No direct action or statement from Ted Striker in the excerpt; he remains absent or inactive during the crisis.
Lost in thought, reflecting on his past struggles and mental health issues.
Elaine shows concern for Ted, indicating he is trusted and cared for by others.
Lost in thought, shown in a dreamlike sequence recalling electro-shock therapy and psychiatric diagnosis, indicating mental instability.
Elaine tells him he was right all along about the crew being lost and Simon turning to jelly, indicating Ted's insight was correct despite his mental state.
Has an empty bottle of stress pills nearby, suggesting reliance on medication and possible inability to manage stress effectively.
Acknowledges his difficult situation and reflects on who his true friends are when he's on the run.
Speaks to the lamb in bed, showing a moment of tenderness despite his troubles.
Leaves the lamb alone to go out for cigarettes and bourbon, indicating a possible neglect or self-centeredness.
Looks both ways and bolts from the mental hospital while wearing a straightjacket, evading guards.
Sits in a fog, seemingly confused and unresponsive to Elaine passing by.
Plans to get cigarettes and bourbon while leaving the lamb unattended, showing casual disregard for responsibility.
Ignores a piano smashing nearby and gives a quizzical look to passersby Gloria and Cab.
Travels at night in shadows, afraid to step out of doorways, minding his own business.
Travels at night in the shadows to avoid attention, showing caution and awareness.
Ignores a piano smashing next to him and gives a quizzical look to passersby, indicating detachment or distraction.
Steps into a puddle and gets sprayed with garbage, then picks up a wet matchbook, showing some inattentiveness to surroundings.
Calmly accepts a lit cigarette from a mysterious woman and draws deeply, showing composure and confidence.
Borrows dark glasses from a blind man causing him to stumble and crash, and takes an alto sax from a passerby causing them to crash as well.
Stays in the background not wanting to draw attention to himself while Elaine enjoys herself.
Encourages Simon to pull himself together and take command despite Simon's drunkenness.
Falls unconscious after being slugged by Simon while trying to help.
Plays saxophone alone on stage after others have left, showing persistence but no direct social warmth.
Confronts Simon about his drunkenness and questions who is in command, showing awareness of the situation.
Attempts to grab Simon and get him to pull himself together, trying to take control of the crisis.
Falls unconscious after being slugged by Simon and hitting his head, temporarily incapacitated.
Responds kindly to a child (Jimmy) asking if he is okay, reassuring him with a friendly tone.
Pushes by Jimmy with a look of great purpose, showing focus but little direct engagement or warmth toward the child.
Lies unconscious and unresponsive during a critical moment.
Wakes up, assesses his condition by feeling his jaw, and pushes forward with a look of great purpose.
Reassures Elaine by saying 'We all make mistakes' and expresses enduring love and forgiveness.
Immediately helps Oveur by picking him up and taking his seat to assist with the situation.
Drags Oveur onto the floor and takes his seat in the cockpit, preparing to take control of the ship.
Engages in a personal, emotional exchange with Elaine instead of responding to urgent radio calls from mission control.
Smiles at Elaine and maintains a friendly demeanor during a tense situation.
Responds to mission control with a humorous and sincere identification.
Hits a switch to perform a barrel roll maneuver with the ship.
Communicates clearly and confidently over the radio identifying himself and his position.
Smiles and remains calm despite chaotic or tense situations.
Communicates clearly and calmly about the emergency situation on the radio, showing concern for the crew and passengers.
Mentions the loss of the rest of the crew and the lack of coffee in a somewhat humorous way, indicating a friendly and relatable demeanor.
Reports clearly and calmly about the electrical fire and the failure of the computer system, indicating situational awareness and communication skills.
Mentions that manual control is impossible and that the captain has already tried it, showing understanding of the situation's limitations.
Wipes his forehead, showing signs of stress but continues to perform his duties.

Makes a somewhat humorous or sarcastic comment about the captain becoming an intolerable bore and the lack of coffee, which could indicate a coping mechanism but might undermine perceived professionalism.
Internally criticizes McCrosky's pep talk, focusing on the real problem (the ship's computer malfunction).
Recognizes that the computer is malfunctioning and identifies the real problem instead of relying on pep talks.
Writes a note to Elaine to coordinate a plan to blow the computer, showing trust and collaboration.
Reassures Elaine and asks her to hold the controls while he goes to handle the problem, showing care and concern.
Leaves to confront the dangerous situation despite the risk, demonstrating responsibility and protective behavior.
Writes a clear, urgent note to Elaine to find a way to blow the malfunctioning computer, showing situational awareness and problem identification.
Delegates control of the plane to Elaine and decides to personally investigate the coffee situation, demonstrating leadership and decisiveness.
Leaves cockpit to check on the coffee system despite the evident danger, showing willingness to take responsibility and act under pressure.
No indication of technical skill or success in fixing the coffee machine yet; the situation worsens with passengers dropping from heat, suggesting limited effectiveness so far.
Disassembles the coffee machine, identifies the melted solder point, and communicates with mission control under pressure.
Fails to prevent a passenger riot triggered by a coffee bean incident.
Attempts to make contact with the coffee machine to presumably trigger or control something important, showing focus and initiative.
Sweats nervously while performing the task, indicating stress but still proceeds with the action.
Causes the coffee machine to explode, resulting in a chaotic gush of coffee, which may indicate a lack of precise control or unintended consequences.
Confronts mission control, criticizes their reckless decisions risking lives.
Accurately assesses the situation by noting they are closer to the sun than estimated.
Engages in a confident and assertive radio exchange, challenging mission control's decisions and holding them accountable.
Misinterprets Elaine's statement about time left as a sexual advance, showing a momentary lapse in focus.
Defends his compassionate stance on radio despite criticism, advocating for social causes like low cost housing.
Responds to Kruger's insult with a calm, thoughtful radio message about alternative spending directives, showing composure and intelligence under pressure.
Has two check marks on the scoreboard compared to Kruger's one, indicating some level of success or progress in the situation.
Shares hopeful moment with Elaine, showing openness to emotional connection.
Quickly informs Mary about the bomb threat to protect others.
Responds calmly to the news of a bomb on board and immediately seeks information about the suspect passenger.
Expresses hope and confidence when receiving news from ground control, showing emotional steadiness.
Relies on ground control's plan without questioning or proposing alternatives.
Instructs Mary to discreetly move passengers to safety without alarming the suspect.
Physically holds back passengers to protect them from danger.
Calms and reasons with Joe, trying to prevent him from harming others and himself.
Assures Joe that no one has to know his problems, showing empathy and understanding.
Tackles Joe to prevent him from causing harm despite public embarrassment.
Instructs Mary to discreetly move passengers to the lounge to avoid alerting the bomber, attempts to calm the situation and reason with Joe to prevent detonation.
Fails to prevent passengers from panicking after Mary announces the bomb, leading to chaos.
Physically tackles Joe to prevent him from escaping with the bomb, showing quick reaction and physical capability.
Responds to McCrosky's instructions with a sarcastic remark about knocking out the wall and hanging plants.
Expresses doubt about using the bomb, showing concern for safety.
Tells Elaine he is going back to the cabin despite danger, showing care and responsibility.
Expresses doubt about using the bomb, calling it a crazy stunt.
Decides to go back to the computer core to attach the time-bomb despite the danger.
Wears a gas mask and carefully ensures it is tight before entering a hazardous environment with gas.
Calmly explains to Elaine the consequences of Simon's premature ejection, showing concern but maintaining composure.
Calmly takes control of the cockpit and assesses the situation with confidence.
Correctly identifies Simon's ejection as premature and predicts the consequences accurately.
Reassures Elaine by acknowledging fear but expressing confidence when together.
Uses a sarcastic remark toward Testa about strapping in.
Acknowledges fear realistically but remains focused and communicates clearly with mission control under pressure.
Uses humor and confidence to manage stress (telling Testa to strap in), showing leadership and calmness.
Demonstrates courage and dedication by preparing to reprogram the ship to avoid disaster despite extreme danger.
Urgently communicates with Elaine to set course change and encourages her with clear, direct commands.
Focuses intensely on controlling the ship and managing the crisis without showing frustration or blame.
Shifts a stick shift on the steering column, preparing to manually control the shuttle after computer failure.
Is described by Kramer as 'the only hope' and 'top dog' responsible for bringing the shuttle in manually.
Fights to maintain control of the cockpit under extreme conditions.
Communicates clearly with Rex Kramer despite the crisis.
Attempts to follow instructions to kill the WORP engines on time.
WORP control handle comes off in his hand, preventing him from executing the command as intended.
Accepts Elaine's help and thanks her sincerely.
Overwhelmed by Elaine's gesture but remains cooperative and focused on the task.
Improvises by using a bobby pin to short-circuit wires and successfully slows down the ship.
Initially confused and overwhelmed by the lack of familiar controls and the situation.
Expresses concern about the ship coming apart and struggles to keep control, showing effort to protect others.
Acknowledges the ship is coming apart and struggles to keep control despite the ship fighting him.
Attempts to follow Kramer's instructions to keep the ship level and nose up.
Expresses difficulty and frustration but continues to try to control the ship.
Fights the controls despite danger and debris, showing determination to protect passengers.
Fights the controls despite the front window being broken and debris covering him and Elaine.
Fails to stop the ship from crashing through various obstacles, causing destruction and terror among passengers and personnel.
Holds Elaine after crash, shares a kiss with her, walks off together showing care and connection.
Successfully executes a difficult landing with guidance, holding the ship steady and following critical timing instructions.
Stops and looks into the distant sky after the landing, showing a moment of uncertainty or contemplation.
Walks with Elaine towards the crawl and politely accepts a flower from strangers.
